title: William Barr met with Rupert Murdoch a day before Donald Trump said Fox News poll 'sucks'
text:
Attorney General William Barr has met for private talks with media mogul Rupert Murdoch as President Donald Trump grows increasingly hostile toward his Fox News Network, it has been reported.

They met at Murdoch's New York home on Wednesday just hours after the network's pollsters published a shocking survey that showed more than half of registered voters want the president removed from office.

Whether anyone else was present at the meeting is not known, New York Times reported, and the subject matter was not shared.

Fox News has been seen as a supporter of Trump throughout his time as both candidate and president, and the president in turn has heaped praise on the network which Murdoch launched in 1996.

However on Thursday morning Trump vented at Fox News Channel in a series of tweets after they released a survey which found 51% of Americans want the president impeached and removed from office.

He wrote: 'From the day I announced I was running for President, I have NEVER had a good @FoxNews Poll. Whoever their Pollster is, they suck.'

New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft was seen talking with Fox Network owner Rupert Murdoch before a game against the New York Giants at Gillette Stadium Thursday

Murdoch met with AG William Barr at his New York home on Wednesday after a Fox News report showed the majority of Americans want Trump impeached and removed

Trump vented on Twitter, saying Fox News pollsters 'suck,' after they found 51 per cent of registered U.S. voters want Congress to impeach him and remove him from office

'But @FoxNews is also much different than it used to be in the good old days,' POTUS continued. 'With people like Andrew Napolitano, who wanted to be a Supreme Court Justice & I turned him down (he’s been terrible ever since), Shep Smith, @donnabrazile (who gave Crooked Hillary the debate questions & got fired from @CNN), & others, @FoxNews doesn’t deliver for US anymore.'

'It is so different than it used to be. Oh well, I’m President!' he sniffed.

That evening Murdoch didn't appear to be too concerned as he was pictured talking to New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft at a New York Giants game inside the Gillette Stadium, Foxborough that night.

This week Kraft filed a complaint against Palm Beach State Attorney Dave Aronberg, just a few months after the Florida office was forced to delay criminal proceedings against the 78-year-old businessman who had been charged with two counts of soliciting a prostitute.

The filmed incidents that happened on back-to-back days at the Orchids of Asia Day Spa in Jupiter.

Murdoch and Kraft chatted around as they watched the teams warm up before an NFL football gameThursday

Murdoch met with Kraft the week Kraft filed a complaint against Palm Beach State Attorney just a few months after the Florida office was forced to delay criminal proceedings against him for charges on two counts of soliciting a prostitute

Those tapes are now high on the list of materials Kraft would like prosecutors to turn over but they have not, which is why his is now demanding declaratory and injunctive relief.

The two men enjoyed the game as Trump fumed according to two White House officials who said Thursday he is becoming increasingly frustrated by daytime news anchors and paid pundits who take pointed shots at him.

The morning show 'Fox & Friends,' along with evening opinion hosts Sean Hannity and Laura Ingraham, have been reliable cheerleaders for the Trump administration.

But Trump directed his anger to more impartial voices Thursday.

President Donald Trump is increasingly frustrated by Fox News Channel daytime anchors and paid pundits who take pointed shots at him, two White House officials said Thursday

Napolitano has denied in the past that he has ever asked Trump for a judicial appointment. In recent months he has morphed into a reliable critic, enraging the president by offering legal analyses that conclude he has committee impeachable offenses.

Fox News polls have been uniformly unfavorable to the president since a month after his inauguration, with 30 polls in a row finding more Americans disapprove of his job performance than approve. The same can be said of most national opinion surveys.

The network released 23 presidential polls in 2015 and 2016 simulating head-to-head contests between Trump and his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton. She prevailed in 18 of them.

Trump came out on top in the last 13 of 22 Fox News polls published during the Republican primary season.

Wednesday's poll results indicated that 51 per cent of registered voters believe Trump should be impeached and removed from office, a nine-point jump from the previous survey on July 19.

Another 4 per cent said the president should be impeached but not removed. Forty per cent opposed impeachment completely.

The president lashed out at Fox News in August after news anchor Sandra Smith interviewed Democratic National Committee Communications Director Xochitl Hinojosa. He tweeted that the press flack was 'spewing out whatever she wanted with zero pushback' from Smith.

'The New @FoxNews is letting millions of GREAT people down! We have to start looking for a new News Outlet. Fox isn’t working for us anymore!' Trump vented.

'Fox hires “give Hillary the questions” @donnabrazile, Juan Williams and low ratings Shep Smith. HOPELESS & CLUELESS! They should go all the way LEFT and I will still find a way to Win,' he tweeted at the time.

Fox on-air personalities fired back.

'Fox News isn’t supposed to work for you,' the network's senior political analyst Brit Hume tweeted.

'We don't work for you,' added contributor and Fox radio host Guy Benson.

Hinojosa blasted the president hours later on MSNBC, saying that 'the fact that he is attacking a Democratic staffer and believes he has control of Fox News is really something else. It tells you a lot about the relationship between Donald Trump and Fox News.'

'This man is running scared. It is laughable,' she said.
description: Rupert Murdoch was involved in private talks with Attorney General William Barr Wednesday as President Donald Trump grew increasingly hostile toward his Fox News Network.
